p: The importance of gestation length and small litters in the BRT model suggest that slow pace of life, more typical of large mammals, may influence susceptibility. Pregnancy in bats, typically small-bodied but with slow life histories, has been linked to both high seroprevalence and seasonal spillover of Hendra, Nipah and Ebola viruses [ 37], suggesting that gestation may be linked to increased risk of viral shedding. Importantly, in BRT analyses, Ebola hosts were more likely among species with gestation lengths more than 100 days across the range of adult body masses ( figureÂ 2). Thus, gestation length itself, rather than simply standing in for life history broadly, may be directly related to susceptibility.
